14    
 
54.  In addition, the Project will employ NGOs to assist local communities in carrying out 
aquaculture  and  related  activities,  and  in  accessing  existing  local  microfinance  schemes. 
Aquaculture  research,  special  studies  and  surveys,  training,  social  preparation,  community 
empowerment, and database development will be contracted to qualified local academic or 
research  institutions  and  consulting  firms.  NGOs/CBOs  and  academic  institutions  will  be 
selected following the least-cost selection and/or single source selection procedures of the 
Guidelines. 
 
5.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 
55.  To monitor and evaluate the operational performance of the agencies and institutions 
involved  and  the  benefits  obtained  from  the  Project,  DGA,  in  consultation  with  ADB,  will 
establish a Project Performance Management System (PPMS) in the PMO within one year of 
loan effectiveness. The PPMS will (i) monitor (both physically and financially) key activities, 
including  consultant  recruitment,  equipment  and  materials  procurement,  training,  surveys, 
special studies, policy development, and the drafting of implementation guidelines; (ii) monitor 
and  rate  the  performance  of  various  stakeholders,  including  local  communities,  in  project 
activities; (iii) monitor the Project’s social, environmental, and economic impacts, and establish 
benchmarks;  and  (iv)  introduce  mechanisms  for  adjusting  project  design  and  project 
implementation arrangements, and for incorporating lessons learned from similar projects into 
project planning. 
 
56.  Consultants will support the PMO in designing a baseline survey and midterm and 
project completion surveys that will help evaluate the financial, economic, and social impacts of 
the  Project.  At  the community  level,  participatory  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  will  be 
introduced as part of the Project’s comprehensive participatory development approach.  Special 
studies may be conducted to investigate issues related to project implementation and impact. 
For  periodic  monitoring,  key  indicators  will  be  developed  and  incorporated  in  the  regular 
reporting system. PMO staff will make regular field visits to monitor progress. Project M&E 
reports will be submitted by the PMO to ADB on a quarterly basis. Upon project completion, 
project impact will be evaluated in accordance with a schedule and TOR to be mutually agreed 
upon by the Government and ADB. 
 
6.  Disbursement Arrangements 
57.  The loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement 
Handbook.  An  imprest  account  will  be  established  at  Bank  Indonesia  in  the  name  of  the 
Executing Agency. The advance to the imprest account will be limited to 10% of the loan 
amount or 6 months projected expenditure, whichever is less. ADB’s statement of expenditure 
procedure will be followed to liquidate funds advanced to the imprest account and will apply to 
contracts not exceeding $100,000. The flow of funds is shown in Supplementary Appendix C. 
7.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
58.  PMO, PIUs, and other agencies involved in project implementation will prepare and 
maintain separate accounts exclusively for the Project and will register in such accounts all 
receipts and payments for the Project in accordance with sound accounting principles and 
procedures. The project accounts will be audited annually by an independent auditor acceptable 
to ADB. An audit opinion of the project accounts will reflect  (i) an assessment of the adequacy 
of  accounting  and  internal  control  systems  with  respect  to  project  expenditures  and  other

15   
financial  transactions,  in  order  to  ensure  safe  custody  of  project-financed  assets;  (ii)  a 
determination as to whether the borrower and project implementing entities have maintained 
adequate documentation of all relevant transactions, including specific mention of SOE and 
special account transactions; (iii) a confirmation that expenditures submitted to ADB are eligible 
for financing, and identification of any ineligible expenditures; and (iv) a confirmation that loan 
covenants and ADB requirements for project management have been complied with. The audit 
opinion needs to be submitted to ADB within six months of the end of the financial year along 
with audited financial statements including opinion on imprest accounts and SOE. 
 
59.  The Government and the EA were informed of ADB’s policy on submission of audited 
accounts, which covers failure to submit audited accounts and financial statements within the 
due time. A formal warning will be issued for accounts more than six months overdue, and 
disbursements will be suspended for accounts more than 12 months overdue. 
 
60.  Reporting systems will be set up at the national and local levels to enable DGA, through 
PMO, to effectively supervise the implementation of all Project activities and provide timely 
advice and support to the PIUs. PMO will be responsible for (i) collecting and consolidating all 
project progress reports, site reports, technical reports, and financial reports; and (ii) preparing 
and submitting to ADB quarterly progress reports, the midterm project evaluation report, and the 
overall project completion report. The PIUs will be responsible for (i) preparing project progress, 
technical,  and  financial  reports  covering  site-specific  activities;  and  (ii)  collecting  and 
consolidating field data and feedback from local participating agencies and contractors that will, 
in turn, be relayed to PMO. Reports will be prepared in a format acceptable to ADB13 and will be 
posted on a project Web site that will be set up under the MMAF Web site. The PMO will be 
staffed with experienced officials with adequate financial management skills and systems. To 
strengthen accountability, the PMO will be responsible for reconciling the PIUs’ financial reports 
and the Project's overall financial accounts, and for posting the consolidated financial report on 
the project Web site for stakeholder examination. At the same time, to maximize transparency at 
the  local  level,  each  PIU  will  provide  copies  of  its  financial  reports  to  the  fish  farmers’ 
associations  and  the  NGOs  responsible  for  the  project  social  preparation  and  community 
empowerment.  These  financial  reports  will  contain  information  on  the  allocated  budget, 
commitments, and disbursements.  
 
8.  Midterm Review  
61.  At the beginning of the fourth year of implementation, a comprehensive midterm review 
of the Project will be carried out to identify any problems and constraints encountered and 
assess  the  need  for  mid-course  modification  of  the  project  scope  and  implementation 
arrangements. Technical and budgetary changes to the project document, arising from PPMS 
findings, will also be considered.  
 
9.  Anticorruption Policy 
62.  The Government was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy and Policy relating to the 
Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism.  Consistent  with  its 
commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability  and  transparency,  ADB  will  require  the 
Government to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls following 
internal best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money laundering 
                                                 
13 The Project will use the template for quarterly reports, which is now being developed by IRM for use by all ADB 
projects in Indonesia.

16    
activities or the financing of terrorism and covenant with ADB to refrain from engaging in such 
activities. The investment documentation between ADB and the Government will further allow 
ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. In particular, all 
contracts financed by ADB in connection with the Project shall include provisions specifying the 
right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of the EA and all contractors, 
suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Project. 
 
63.  The project design and implementation arrangements provide for mitigating corruption 
risks. The participatory management of the project with the implementation responsibility shared 
by DGA and districts governments and the involvement of NGOs and CBOs in field level 
activities will improve transparency and accountability in the decision making process. The cost-
sharing arrangement will motivate district governments and beneficiaries to strive for economy 
and efficiency in project implementation and avoid corrupt practices. 
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic Benefits 
64.  The  Project’s  major  quantifiable  economic  benefit  will  be  increased  aquaculture 
production and productivity. By improving access infrastructure, promoting competitive fish and 
shrimp hatcheries and nurseries, providing post-harvest and processing facilities, and providing 
marketing support, the Project will significantly reduce transaction costs and increase farmgate 
prices of aquaculture products. The introduction of new culture techniques or new aquaculture 
commodities through pilot demonstrations, based on applied research results, will improve 
aquaculture yields. Financial analysis for five representative activities (grouper cage culture, 
mud-crab fattening, seaweed production, carp ponds culture, and tiger shrimp cultivation) at the 
farm level was undertaken to determine the financial viability of aquaculture in the post-project 
scenario. All of the representative aquaculture activities exhibit financial internal rate of return 
(FIRR) values significantly above the prevailing financial cost of capital of 22%, and they were 
not  sensitive  to  major  risks  (Appendix  12  and  details  in  Supplementary  Appendix  D).  To 
determine the economic viability of the Project, economic internal rate of return (EIRR) values 
were  estimated  for  representative  aquaculture  activities.  The  anticipated  EIRR  values  for 
individual schemes ranged from 15% to 21%. 
 
65.  The strengthening of extension services will enhance the sustainability of aquaculture 
enterprises by improving the provision of continuous technical support and training to fish 
farmers.  The  establishment  of  research–extension  linkages  between  provincial  and  district 
fisheries services will facilitate the commercial application of research results by fish farmers, 
which in turn will lead to improvements in aquaculture productivity in project sites. Aquaculture 
training and demonstrations for fish farmers will not only lead to establishment of small-scale 
enterprises, but will also provide technically educated labor for medium-scale enterprises. The 
improvement in financial returns for aquaculture as a result of project activities should lead to 
more  private  sector  participation.  In  addition,  the  Project  is  expected  to  result  in  (i) 
environmental benefits arising from improved aquaculture resources management at the district 
and  village  levels;  (ii)  improved  nutrition  and  health  of  rural  populations  stemming  from 
expanded food supplies and increased consumption of animal protein; (iii) enhanced inter-
agency and public–private sector linkages through strengthened partnerships in aquaculture 
development;  and  (iv)  empowerment  of  small  fish  farmers  and  rural  communities  with 
knowledge  and  skills  in  community-based  aquaculture  and  culture-based  fisheries 
management.

17   
B.  Social Measures and Impact on Poverty 
66.  The Project will reduce poverty by boosting incomes, employment, and food security. 
The  socioeconomic  survey  conducted  during  project  preparation  showed  that  poverty 
incidence14 among aquaculture households in the project districts ranges from 26% to 48%. The 
total population at risk15 is estimated at 203,664, or 60% of the aquaculture population in the 
project districts. The Project is expected to help 14,000 poor households to increase their 
incomes to levels above the poverty line. Not only will the Project engage about 18,000 person-
years of labor in aquaculture, but it will also create many jobs in the aquaculture industry’s 
supply chain (transportation of goods, processing of byproducts such as fish fry and terasi, fish 
trading, etc.). A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is given in Appendix 13.  
 
67.  The  Project  will  require  minimal  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and  will  not 
involve significant involuntary resettlement as described in the ADB’s policy on involuntary 
resettlement. The subproject selection criteria (Appendix 5) ensure that only subprojects with 
minimal land acquisition will be approved. Details of land acquisition will be known only after the 
subprojects are identified at detailed design level. The Project has established a compensation 
policy framework and procedural guidelines (Supplementary Appendix F) to be followed in the 
preparation of the needed resettlement plans. Buton district has large populations of indigenous 
peoples  and  it  is likely  that  some  of  them  will  be  affected  once  the  subprojects  are  fully 
identified. To guide the preparation of needed indigenous peoples development plans, DGA has 
prepared an indigenous peoples development framework reflecting the requirements of ADB’s 
policy on indigenous peoples (Supplementary Appendix G).    
 
68.  The project scope will meet women’s needs and improve their socioeconomic status 
getting  them  more  involved  in  aquaculture,  culture-based  fisheries,  and  related  activities, 
including fish processing, trading, and community-based monitoring. Several gender-responsive 
activities dealing with women’s reproductive, productive, and community management roles 
have been incorporated into the project design. The Project will support poor women in gaining 
access to resources, technical assistance, and capacity-building efforts for poverty reduction 
and food security. Women will be included in all project activities, including those dealing with 
production  inputs  assistance  and  training.  To  ensure  that  the  Project  addresses  gender 
concerns women will be hired to conduct gender training to sensitize local government officials 
and  personnel  to  women’s  needs.  Baseline  PPMS  surveys  and  the  midterm  and  project 
completion surveys will collect gender-disaggregated data. Gender indicators will be included in 
the PPMS and will become an important element in the evaluation system for the PMO and 
NGOs. Specific targets for women participation in project activities are given in Appendix 13, 
Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy, Section D.  
 
C.  Environment 
69.  The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  conducted  during  project  preparation 
showed that none of the interventions are projected to have significant or adverse impacts on 
the environment. A few minor environmental impacts are likely as a result of factors related to 
site selection, construction, and operation, but these are small and avoidable and could be 
minimized  through  careful  planning  and  the  adoption  of  proper  construction  practices. 
Appropriate environmental safeguards have been built into project design to mitigate against 
these likely negative effects. A summary IEE is given in Appendix 14.  
                                                 
14 The poverty incidence rate for the districts was based on the Rp3.2 million poverty threshold. 
15  Defined as those under the poverty threshold plus those just above the poverty line.

18    
 
D.  Risks and Countermeasures 
70.  The risks that could affect project implementation and constrain the attainment of project 
objectives are: (i) institutional inadequacies of DGA and the district governments; (ii) lack of 
cooperation and coordination between DGA and the district governments, and between the 
district  fisheries  service  and  other  local  government  agencies;  (iii)  lack  of  Government 
counterpart funds, (iv) lack of interest of the private sector to participate in the Project; (v) 
reluctance  of  poor  fish  farmers  to  adopt  new  or  improved  technologies;  (vi)  adverse 
environmental  impacts  resulting  from  more  intensive  culture  practices;  and  (vii)  misuse  of 
project funds and facilities. 
 
71.  The risks arising from institutional inadequacies, lack of coordination between agencies, 
and lack of counterpart funds will be minimized by the (i) the establishment of NSC and RAC 
with functions aimed at promoting effective coordination of project implementation; (ii) provision 
of competent project management staff by DGA and the participating district governments; (iii) 
vigorous  implementation  of  the  Project’s  institutional  strengthening  component,  including  a 
massive training program for all stakeholders; (iv) adoption of a “learning approach” to project 
implementation, whereby relatively new technologies are demonstrated and pilot-tested prior to 
full-scale implementation; (v) establishment of close working relationships among NGOs/CBOs, 
extension staff, participating rural communities, and the private sector; (vi) provision of project 
management  specialist  services  to  assist  and  support  PMO,  PIUs,  and  local  extension 
personnel; and (vii) design and implementation of an effective monitoring and reporting system, 
with a view to obtaining prompt feedback and enabling timely remedies.  
 
72.  It is not likely that the private sector will lack interest given that the Project will provide 
various incentives for their participation, such as upgrades to infrastructure (e.g. access roads, 
post-harvest processing facilities, and water-quality and fish-health laboratories). The private 
sector will also have ample opportunity to access Project support and to participate in training 
programs to upgrade their skills in aquaculture and related fields. 
 
73.  The rapid social assessment surveys performed during project preparation found that 
fish farmers are highly interested in participating in the Project and willing to adopt new or 
improved  fish-farming  technologies  to  improve  output  and  yields.  Moreover,  the  social 
preparation and community organizing work to be carried out by contracted NGOs will build 
upon this interest and prepare fish farmers for participation in the Project. Existing practice of 
monitoring  of  development  projects  by  civil  society  organizations  will  also  help  preventing 
corruption at the district level. Finally, the possibility of adverse environmental impacts resulting 
from project interventions will be mitigated by a number of project design features including 
environmental management training, laboratory facilities for monitoring water quality and fish 
health,  adoption  of  low-density  culture,  and  selection  of  species  that  are  either  naturally 
available or successfully cultured and adapted elsewhere in the country. 
 
74.  On  the  whole,  therefore,  the  technical  soundness  of  the  proposed  production  and 
support  interventions  and  the  adoption  of  participatory  approaches  and  social  preparation 
activities in project implementation will result in the benefits exceeding the costs.

19   
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
75.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government and MMAF have given the 
following assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
(i)  The  Government  ensures,  and  will  cause  each  of  the  participating  district 
governments to ensure, that counterpart funds for the project implementation will 
be  provided  on  time.  Further  the  Government,  and  the  participating  district 
governments, will make timely submission of annual budgetary appropriation 
request and ensure prompt disbursement of appropriated funds during each year 
of project implementation. 
(ii)  The Government, through MMAF, and the participating district governments will 
make  available  required  number  of  qualified  staff  throughout  Project 
implementation, to be assigned to the PMO and the PIUs. The PMO will be 
headed by a dedicated Project Director with the support of a Project Manager, 
with experience and expertise acceptable to ADB, and supported by the required 
technical, administrative and financial staff. The PIUs will comprise a dedicated 
PIU Head, with experience and expertise acceptable to ADB, and the required 
technical, administrative and financial staff. 
(iii)  Within one year of loan effective date MMAF will establish a project performance 
management system (PPMS), which will encompass (a) monitoring of physical 
and financial progress as well as economy and efficiency of key activities such as 
recruitment  of  consultants,  procurement  of  equipment  and  materials,  training 
arrangements,  conduct  of  surveys  and  special  studies,  policy  development, 
drafting of implementation guidelines, and the like; (b) monitoring of the level and 
adequacy of participation of various stakeholders, including local communities, in 
Project  activities;  (c)  monitoring  of  the  Project’s  social,  environmental,  and 
economic impacts, including the establishment of benchmark information and 
data; and (d) setting a mechanism for making necessary adjustments in the 
project  design  and  implementation  arrangement  and  incorporating  lessons 
learned from similar projects  in Project planning.  
(iv)  At the community level, participatory monitoring and evaluation (M&E) will be 
introduced  as  part  of  the  Project’s  comprehensive  participatory  development 
approach. The M&E will be prepared in the form and substance agreed between 
the Government and ADB and will be submitted to ADB on a quarterly basis. 
(v)  The Government will ensure that only subprojects and beneficiaries meeting the 
eligibility criteria for selection set out in Appendix 5 of this document receive 
funding under the Project. 
(vi)  The Government will ensure and will cause each of the participating district 
governments to ensure that prior to the award of civil works contracts, it shall 
screen for involuntary resettlement effects to ensure that there are no losses of 
land, income, housing, community facilities and resources that would require 
compensation  to  be  paid  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  policy  on  Involuntary 
Resettlement. In the event land acquisition and resettlement is required for any 
activities funded under the Project, such land acquisition and resettlement shall 
be carried out in accordance with the agreed Compensation Policy Framework 
and Procedural Guidelines prepared for the Project. 
(vii)  The  Government  will  ensure,  or  will  cause  each  of  the  participating  district 
governments  to  ensure,  that  the  gender  action  plan,  as  described  in  the

20    
Appendix 13 to this document, is complied with, in order to ensure (a) equal 
opportunities for men and women in all project activities, including aquaculture 
development,  processing,  marketing,  resource  management  and  livelihood 
programs; (b) equal opportunity for women to access financial assistance; and (c) 
achievement of specific targets set out therein.  
(viii)  The Government will ensure that one PMO staff member is designated as the 
gender focal point, with responsibility for organizing gender training, coordinating 
gender-related activities, advising on how gender concerns can be incorporated 
in project activities, and monitoring the extent to which this is done.  
(ix)  The site selection, design, construction and operation of the aquaculture facilities 
and social infrastructure will be implemented in accordance with the relevant 
government  regulations  and  standards  as  well  as  the  ADB’s  Environmental 
Policy  and  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines.  Further,  all  aquaculture 
facilities, social infrastructure, and microenterprise activities will be subjected to 
an environmental screening prior to their establishment. 
(x)  The Government will ensure that all necessary measures will be taken under the 
Project with regard to indigenous peoples in accordance with the Indigenous 
Peoples’ Development Framework and ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples.  
(xi)  Project accounts, including financial statements, SOEs, and imprest account, 
together with disbursement documents, will be audited annually by independent 
auditors acceptable to ADB and will be submitted to ADB not later than six 
months after the end of each fiscal year. 
B.  Condition for Loan Effectiveness 
76.  Prior to loan effectiveness, the National Steering Committee and Regional Advisory 
Committees shall have been established. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
77.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 22,352,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the 
Sustainable Aquaculture Development for Food Security and Poverty Reduction Project from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during 
the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 
8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Aquaculture Resources and Production Performance 
1.  Indonesia  has  8.3  million  hectares  (ha)  of  coastal  waters  suitable  for  mariculture; 
2.15 million ha of rivers, lakes, ponds, and paddy fields suitable for freshwater aquaculture; and 
about 1,224,000 ha of brackishwater ponds. However, the actual area devoted to aquaculture is 
currently estimated at only 810,000 ha, representing less than 7% of the total potential area. 
Nevertheless, the existing aquaculture area is almost double that devoted to aquaculture in 
1980, when there were only 316,000 ha of fishponds, 89,000 ha of rice paddies that were used 
for fish culture, and only 2 ha of fish cages. Aquaculture and inland water capture fisheries 
contribute 26% to the country’s total fish production. Total aquaculture production increased by 
about 10% per year between 1994 and 2005, from 597,520 metric tons (t) to 2.1 million t. 
Technological innovations, area expansion, and availability of suitable quality and quantity of fish 
seed drove this increase. 
 
2.  Freshwater  Aquaculture.    This  was  the  earliest  form  of  aquaculture  in  Indonesia, 
starting in the middle of the 19th century with the stocking of common carp in backyard ponds in 
West Java, and subsequently expanding to other parts of Java, Sumatera, and Sulawesi islands 
in the early 20th century. However, it was only in the late 1970s when a remarkable increase in 
production  from  freshwater  aquaculture  was  observed—a  result  of  the  introduction  of  new 
farming technologies, which contributed to the availability of hatchery-produced seed, and the 
development  of  compound  fish  feeds.  The  main  freshwater  producing  regions  are  Java, 
Sumatera, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, Bali, Nusa Tenggara, and Maluku-Papua, which altogether 
produced some 629,635 t in 2005. Common carp is the most dominant species, with production 
comprising about half of the total freshwater aquaculture output. The production of common carp 
in ponds, cages, and paddy fields doubled from 1988 to 2001, with the bulk (64%) coming from 
Java, where it is widely preferred by the local people. Other common culture species are tilapia 
(Oreochromis  niloticus),  gouramy  (Osphronemus  gouramy),  and  on  a  limited  scale  the 
freshwater  prawn  (Macrobrachium  rosenbergii).  The  Asian  catfish  (Pangasius  spp.),  locally 
known as Patin Bangkok, was recently introduced into the country, and its production has been 
growing rapidly, especially in Sumatera. 
 
3.  Brackishwater Aquaculture. Milkfish (Chanos chanos) remains the primary species for 
brackishwater aquaculture at present, with production reaching about 644,000 t in 2005, almost 
double the 140,000 t produced in 1997. In terms of value, however, penaeid shrimp is the prime 
commodity, contributing 80% to total fisheries exports. However, because outbreaks of white 
spot virus resulted in mass mortalities in ponds, tiger shrimp production stagnated at around 
90,000 t from 1997-2001. In the previous years, shrimp production had risen dramatically from a 
low of 77,451 t in 1988 to a high of 167,117 t in 1997. Private farmers continue to grow penaeid 
shrimp, albeit on a much reduced scale compared with the 1980s and 1990s. The production of 
tiger shrimp dropped significantly in recent years. To compensate for the drop in jumbo tiger 
shrimp production in the wake of recent disease outbreaks, white shrimp (Penaeus vannamei) 
and  rostris  shrimp  (Litopenaeus  stylirostris),  which  are  sturdier  than  tiger  shrimp,  were 
introduced by the Government and are now successfully farmed in East Java, Lampung, and 
Bali, where the average yield is 10 t/ha/crop. 
 
4.  Mariculture.  The main mariculture species in Indonesia are (i) high-value finfish such as 
seabass  (Lates  calcarifer),  groupers  (Epinephelus  spp.,  Cromileptes  altivelis,  Plectropomus 
spp.), and snappers (Lutjanus argentimaculatus, L. sebae); (ii) mollusks, including  oysters such 
as  the  gold-lipped  pearl  oyster  (Pinctada  maxima),  the  black-lipped  pearl  oyster  (Pinctada

Appendix 2  27 
margaritifera), and the wing oyster (Pteria penguin); clams, turban snails (Trochus miloticus), 
abalone (Haliotis assinina), cockles, and mussels (Perna viridis); seaweeds (Eucheuma cottonii, 
E.  spinosum,  Gracilaria  sp.,  Gelidium  sp.),  and  other  species,  including  sea  cucumber 
(Holothuria  sp.),  also  known  as  beche-de-mer  or  trepang.  Research  and  experimentation 
involving other marine species believed to have good production potential have been ongoing at 
the different aquaculture research centers. Other candidate species for mariculture include the 
swimming crab (Portunus pelagicus), mudcrab (Scylla paramamosain), bigeye trevally (Caranx 
sexfaciatus), golden trevally (Gnathonodon speciosus), Napoleon wrasse (Cheilinus undulatus), 
and big-fin squid (Seploteuthis lessoniana). Preliminary results of the growout of humpback 
grouper  (Cromileptes  altivelis)  and  tiger  grouper  (erinephelus  fuscoguttatus)  in  cages  in 
Lempuing Bay (South Sumatera) were recently made available and indicate very good financial 
returns. 
 
B.  Markets for Indonesian Aquaculture Products 
5.  Most aquaculture products are consumed domestically, with a local demand high for 
milkfish, common carp, and tilapia in Java, Sulawesi, Lampung, and inland areas of Sumatera. 
In addition to the domestic market, aquaculture products are exported to various countries. In 
2001, shrimp produced through aquaculture comprised 76% of total shrimp exports, while crab 
produced through aquaculture comprised 46% of total crab exports and seaweed produced 
through aquaculture comprised 88% of total seaweed exports. Other aquaculture commodities 
with good export potential include grouper, tilapia, milkfish, channel catfish, and ornamental 
fish. 
 
6.  Supply and Demand Outlook. The demand for fish products is expected to increase 
over the period 2006–2014. The projected annual demand for fish was calculated based on 
projections of total population and fish consumption per capita. Applying an annual growth rate 
of 1.2%, the Central Bureau of Statistics (BPS) projects the total population of Indonesia to 
increase from 216.4 million people in 2004 to 243.4 million people in 2014. Per capita fish 
consumption, based on simple regression analysis using per capita fish consumption time 
series data for the period 1993–2005, is projected to increase from 22.67kg/capita to 31.14 
kg/capita  between  2005  and  2014.  Given  these  scenarios,  total  annual  fish  demand  is 
expected to increase from 5.5 million t in 2005 to 7.6 million t in 2014, as shown in Table A1.1 
below. 
 
7.  Estimates of total annual fish supply for the period 2006–2014 were based on annual 
projections of total fish production (i.e., marine capture fisheries, inland capture fisheries, and 
aquaculture  fisheries)  and  the  difference  between  fish  exports  and  imports.  Annual  fish 
production  from  marine  capture  fisheries,  inland  capture  fisheries,  and  aquaculture  was 
projected based on 1988–2005 time series data and the application of regression analysis. Fish 
production from marine fisheries is projected to increase by 7% over the 2005–2014 period, 
while production from inland fisheries is projected to increase by 2% and from aquaculture 
fisheries by 75% over the same period. Projections of annual fish exports and imports also relied 
on estimates of annual growth rates derived from regression analysis (see footnotes in Table 
A1.1). The results of the projections of fish exports and imports indicate that the country will 
remain  a  net  exporter  of  fish  and  fish  products.  Total  fish  supply  available  for  domestic 
consumption is expected to increase from 5.2 million t in 2005 to 6.4 million t in 2014, which is 
still below the amount required to satisfy total demand. The estimated fish demand gap was 
about 263,000 t in 2005, and is projected to increase to about 1,143,000 t in 2014.

C.  Aquaculture Support Facilities and Services 
 
  1.  Infrastructure Facilities 
   
8.  Various physical infrastructure facilities and services are in place to support the local 
aquaculture industry. First, a large number of fish seed production facilities, fish disease 
laboratories, and technical implementing units provide support to field operations. There are 
numerous public and private fish and shrimp hatcheries in various parts of the country. Fish 
disease laboratories have also been established by the Government at five sites, namely: (i) 
Karawang, West Java; (ii) Indramayu, West Java; (iii) Maribaya (Tegal), Central Java; (iv) 
Bangil, East Java; and (v) Pangkep, South Sulawesi. Technical implementing units reporting to 
the DGA have been set up in 12 sites to develop hatchery and fish culture techniques for 
transfer to the private sector and provide fish farmers with technical support services in fish 
health and environmental management. 
 
9.   In 2002, there were about 12,500 small- and medium-scale processing facilities in 30 
provinces and about 600 industrial fish-processing plants for various fish and aquatic products. 
The product is exported to Asian countries, the United States, Canada, and the European 
Union. More than half (339) of the industrial processing plants have been implementing the 
Hazard Analysis for Critical Control Point (HACCP) program for quality and safety assurance 
for fisheries products and are eligible to export products to the EU. Ice plants and cold-storage 
facilities are part of the functional facilities of the fishing ports, which usually have designated 
industrial areas for handling and post-harvest activities, ice plants, and cold storage.  
 
10.  In most district capitals, there are public markets with areas specifically designated for 
fish sales. In Jakarta City, there are over 200 public markets, large and small, which cater to the 
day-to-day  needs  of  the  general  public  for  seafood,  particularly  for  middle-  to  low-income 
consumers. Muara Baru, Jakarta, has a wholesale fish market where marine fish is traded every 
night. The wholesale fish market in Sukabumi is mainly for freshwater live fish, including fry and 
fingerlings. 
 
  2.  Research, Training, and Extension 
   
11.  Aquaculture research currently focuses on the development of methods, techniques, and 
systems for commodities with potential for commercial production. Product-processing research, 
on the other hand, centers on adding value for fisheries and aquatic products through the 
advanced  processing  techniques  and  quality  improvement.  Strategic  marine  and  fisheries 
research is the main responsibility of the Agency for Marine and Fisheries Research (AMFR), 
which has three research institutes under its Research Center for Aquaculture, one each for 
mariculture, freshwater aquaculture, and brackishwater aquaculture. 
 
12.  Education  and  Training.    MMAF  has  three  institutes  of  higher  learning  under  its 
administration: a fisheries institute in Jakarta, an aquaculture academy in Sidoardjo and an 
aquaculture  academy  in  Sorong.  Seven  fisheries  high  schools  train  middle-level  fisheries 
personnel and field extension workers. These are located in Aceh, Kota Agung, Pariaman, 
Tegal, Bone, Pontianak, and Ambon. In addition, there are five fisheries training centers—in 
Medan, Tegal, Banyuwangi, Bitung, and Ambon. On average, each school produces at least 40 
fisheries graduates per year with specialization in various fields. 
 
13.  Extension.    With  the  establishment  of  MMAF  and  the  passage  of  the  Regional 
Autonomy  Law,  both  in  1999,  fisheries  extension  services  were  devolved  to  district

30  Appendix 2 
governments. Depending on the relative importance of fisheries to the local economy, extension 
services have either been performed by a separate fisheries service (i.e., the Dinas Kelautan 
dan Perikanan [district fisheries service]) or have been embedded within the Dinas for livestock 
and fisheries.1 As a result of devolution of fisheries extension to the local governments, there is 
no longer a national government agency that is primarily responsible for (i) formulating fisheries 
extension  policy,  (ii)  developing  programs  and  technical  guidelines,  (iii)  providing  technical 
guidance for extension workers, and (iv) carrying out strategic extension activities with inter-
ministerial ramifications. 
 
14.  At the local level, governments generally lack the preparation, resources, and capacity to 
take on active extension and coordination roles. The organizational structures differ from one 
district to another, but these structures are usually weak and lack responsiveness to evolving 
fisher/fish farmer aspirations and needs. Extension workers suffer from low morale and lack of 
motivation resulting from deficiencies in job design, appraisal, and incentive systems. Human 
resource  systems,  including  selection,  deployment,  and  promotion,  are  also  deficient.  The 
extension systems for aquaculture lack an integrated, cross-sector approach, and the level of 
aquaculture technology entering the formal extension system is severely limited because of 
weak extension–research linkages. In addition, budgetary, human resource, and institutional 
limitations have severely hampered the transfer of technology to poor fishers and fish farmers.  
 
D.  Sector Issues 
 
15.  Indonesia’s aquaculture subsector is confronted with numerous problems, most notably: 
(i) high incidence of poverty among small fish farmers, (ii) environmental degradation, (iii) low 
growth and productivity caused by poor farm management and lack of good quality seeds, (iv) 
lack of credit facilities for poor fish farmers, (v) lack of post-production facilities and marketing 
infrastructure, and (vi) lack of social preparation and inefficient extension services. The financial 
crisis of 1997 further aggravated the accessibility of credit and effectively increased the prices of 
imported inputs like feeds and chemicals. 
 
16.  The  industry  suffers  from  low  productivity  as  a  result  of  technical,  economic,  and 
environmental factors. Small fish farmers usually practice extensive culture using low-yielding, 
low-input, and low-level technology, and lack the technical know-how or skills to enable them to 
adopt new or improved production methods and techniques. Their problems are compounded, in 
some areas, by the occurrence of fish or shrimp diseases, which are usually triggered by poor 
environmental quality, inferior seed quality, poor hatchery and culture management, and other 
factors. Small-scale fish farmers also lack sufficient funds to shift to higher-density farming or 
higher value commodities. Problems associated with aquaculture business ventures (e.g., low 
production performance, disease occurrence, and fluctuating prices) have contributed to the 
image of aquaculture as a high-risk industry. Financial institutions have therefore been reluctant 
to extend credit to fish farmers—especially small fish farmers. Formal financial institutions also 
generally require collateral and proof of ability to repay loans, which small fish farmers lack. This 
leaves small fish farmers reliant on their own labor and meager financial resources to run their 
subsistence culture operations. If they do manage to secure loans, it is usually from informal 
lending sources which don't require collateral but demand usurious interest rates. 
 
                                                 
1  For example, among the districts selected for inclusion in the proposed Project, only Buton has a separate Dinas 
Kelautan dan Perikanan; in the others, fisheries functions are carried out by the Dinas for livestock/agriculture and 
fisheries

Appendix 2  31 
17.  The combination of factors outlined above has resulted in low incomes and poor quality 
of life for small fish farmers. Their incomes fall way below the national average, and they have 
limited or no access to basic social services such as health, education, water supply, sanitation, 
transport, and communication. Literacy levels are very low, mortality and morbidity rates are 
high, and more than one-third of small farmers and fishers live below the poverty line.  
 
18.  Aside from the above technical and socioeconomic issues, there are policy, legal, and 
institutional constraints hampering the further development of aquaculture. In the area of policy 
and legislation, the passage of Law 32/2004 on Regional Governance, which called for the 
devolution of a number of fisheries management responsibilities from the central government to 
the local governments, has various implications for the sector. Firstly, there is general ambiguity 
in the definition of roles of the central, provincial, and district governments, especially as those 
roles pertain to marine and coastal management. Secondly, the responsibility for aquaculture 
development  and  spatial  planning  for  aquaculture  activities  now  lies  with  the  regional 
governments, except when foreign investments are involved, in which case DGA review and 
recommendation are required prior to approval by the regional government concerned. Thirdly, 
while the central government retains responsibility for formulating criteria for determining and 
changing the land use of areas designated for aquaculture, the regional government makes the 
final decision on whether or not to consider such criteria in the preparation of their regional 
spatial plans. Fourthly, the local governments that are suddenly empowered to handle such 
technical responsibilities lack the capacity (in terms of knowledge, skills, and resources) to 
adequately perform their tasks. 
 
19.  Finally, and most importantly, with the devolution of fisheries extension to the local 
governments,  a  national  government  agency  no  longer  has  primary  responsibility  for  (i) 
formulating  fisheries  extension  policy,  (ii)  developing  extension  programs  and  technical 
guidelines, (iii) providing technical guidance to extension workers, and (iv) carrying out strategic 
extension  activities  with  inter-ministerial  ramifications.  To  make  matters  worse,  local 
governments generally lack the preparation, resources, and capacity to take on active extension 
development and coordination. The result is an extension organization that is structurally weak 
and non-responsive to evolving fish farmer needs. The extension systems for aquaculture in 
particular  lack  an  integrated,  cross-sector  approach.  The  level  of  aquaculture  technology 
entering the formal extension system is severely limited by weak extension–research linkages, 
inadequate technology adoption, and inadequate technology transfer to end-users.

Appendix 5  35 
CRITERIA FOR SELECTION OF SUBPROJECT SITES AND BENEFICIARIES 
 
1.  The five project districts were selected based on the following main criteria: (i) they have 
good  potential  for  further  resource  development  and  are  in  need  of  improved  aquaculture 
systems to raise productivity and protect the environment; (ii) they exhibit high poverty incidence 
among the agricultural population (based on data and information from the Central Bureau of 
Statistics, 2002); (iii) the district government is committed to improving aquaculture production 
and socioeconomic conditions for fish farmers; and (iv) the limited financial capacity of the 
district government constrains further investment in aquaculture. 
 
2.  Within each district, subdistricts were selected based mainly on the aquatic resource 
base and its potential for development, and on the socioeconomic conditions for local fish 
farmers.  Within  an  identified  subdistrict,  it  is  the  district  government  and  the  local  project 
implementation unit (PIU) that will, within a year of project launch, identify villages and fish 
farmers eligible to participate in the Project. The general criteria for selection of subprojects are 
shown in the following box: 
 
A. Selection Criteria for Culture Species 
1.  Species must have been previously cultured in the country and not harm indigenous 
species in the area. 
2.  Its rate of growth must be sufficiently high. 
3.  It must be able to reproduce successfully under culture conditions. 
4.  It must accept and thrive on abundant and cheap artificial feeds. 
5.  It must be acceptable to the target consumers. 
6.  It should be able to support a high population density in ponds or cages. 
7.  It must have a high resistance to disease. 
8.  Seeds must be available and easy to obtain. 
 
B. Selection Criteria for Technology to be Adopted 
1.  The technology should be simple, low-cost, and low-level to facilitate transfer to, and 
adoption by, fish farmers and have greater chances of success. 
2.  More complex technologies which require higher capital and other inputs are better 
suited to medium- and large-scale private entrepreneurs with the capability to engage 
the services of technical specialists in running their operations. 
 
C. Criteria for the Siting of Brackishwater Aquaculture and Mariculture Subprojects 
1.  The subproject should not be located in environmentally critical areas, such as protected 
forests, marine sanctuaries, or nature reserves.  
2.  The subproject should not involve the conversion of mangrove forests into fishponds. 
3.  The subproject should not involve the destruction of coastal habitats such as coral reefs 
and seagrass beds and associated flora and fauna. 
4.  Ample  attention  must  be  paid  to  site  selection,  culture  installation  design,  and  the 
management of culture operations to preserve the integrity of the environment.  
5.  Integrated aquaculture, such as maintaining of mangroves along fishpond dikes and in 
nearby areas, should be encouraged for environmental conservation. 
6.  The subproject will involve minimal land acquisition and resettlement.

first year of implementation. A preliminary list of selection criteria for small-scale fish farmers to

groups”  as  defined  in  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development  Plan  and  Annual

the community; and (vi) must be willing to be supervised and monitored by project personnel.

credit funds available under existing national and local credit programs.

Appendix 12  47 
FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 
 
1.  Financial  and  economic  analyses  are  undertaken  to  evaluate  the  viability  and 
sustainability  of  the  selected  aquaculture  activities  selected  for  the  Project.  The  economic 
analysis provides the economic rationale of the Project and determines its economic viability. 
The financial analysis examines the financial sustainability of the selected subproject schemes 
from the fish farmers’ point of view. 
 
A.  Major Assumptions 
2.  The economic analysis is based on the assumptions outlined in the following sections: 
 
1.  Prices 
 
3.  Financial  benefits  and  costs  are  estimated  in  constant  2006  prices.  All  prices  are 
expressed at the world market price level in the national currency. Financial farmgate prices are 
based on findings of surveys undertaken during the feasibility study in 2004 and adjusted to the 
inflation rate. For this analysis, the prevailing interbank exchange rate of Rp9,000 per US dollar 
is used; opportunity cost of capital is assumed at 12%. 
 
4.  Labor costs have been shadow-priced at 0.65 of the wage rates, while nontradable 
inputs have been adjusted by the standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.90. The financial 
analysis considers only hired labor, while the economic analysis includes estimations of both 
family and hired labor.  
 
2.  Period of Economic Analysis 
 
5.  The economic life of the Project is assumed to be 20 years, from 2007 to 2026. The 
major project activities will be implemented over a 6-year period from 2007 to 2013.      
 
3.  Project Economic Costs 
 
6.  The economic costs of the Project are estimated at $38.82 million.1 The economic price 
of land was calculated by adjusting the prevailing market prices by the SCF.   
 
4.  Project Economic Benefits 
 
7.  The Project will promote the establishment and development of aquaculture enterprises 
by providing technical skills development to fish farmers, improving infrastructure and marketing 
support to the fish farmers, and strengthening extension services and policies and regulations 
for aquaculture and related activities.  
 
8.  Aquaculture products are usually purchased live by traders at the farm site. A portion of 
these products is sold to retailers (either live or fresh) at local markets within the district. The rest 
is sold to other urban markets such as Jakarta, Palembang, Medan, Bandung, and Surabaya, or 
directly to exporters who ship the commodities to international markets. There are, however, 
some prevailing site-specific constraints that cause inefficiencies in the marketing flow in the 
                                                 
1  The economic costs of the Project were derived from subtracting the price contingencies and transfer payments 
(taxes and duties) from the financial total project costs.

48  Appendix 12 
districts. These include: (i) the poor condition of pathways and farm-to-market roads at farm 
sites, particularly in shrimp production areas such as OKI, Karawang, and Langkat; (ii) the large 
number of small fish farmers, which makes it difficult and costly for traders to assemble fish 
products; (iii) a lack of fish receiving and marketing stations where farmers and traders can meet 
and transact business; and (v) a lack of proper seaweed-drying facilities. These constraints have 
contributed to high procurement costs—specifically transportation costs—among traders, which 
have resulted in smaller margins relative to those received by farmers. In the ‘without Project’ 
scenario, it is assumed that these factors continue to constrain aquaculture sector growth; 
hence, production levels remain the same. In the ‘with Project’ scenario, fish production is 
expected to grow at 6.4% annually.  
 
9.  In  the  ”with  Project”  scenario,  the  main  quantifiable  benefit  will  be  in  the  form  of 
incremental aquaculture production. By improving access infrastructure and fish post-harvest 
and processing facilities, promoting competitive fish/shrimp hatcheries and nurseries to support 
seed  requirements,  and  providing  marketing  support,  the  Project  will  significantly  reduce 
transaction costs and increase farmgate prices of aquaculture products. The introduction of new 
culture techniques or new aquaculture commodities through pilot demonstrations, based on 
applied research results, will improve aquaculture yields.  
 
10.  Apart  from  aquaculture  production  benefits,  the  Project  will  generate  a  number  of 
benefits that are not readily quantifiable. Community organizing and institutional strengthening of 
district  governments  are  among  the  most  important  elements  of  project  design.  The 
strengthening of extension services will enhance the sustainability of aquaculture by improving 
the provision of continuous technical support and training to fish farmers. The establishment of 
research–extension  linkages  between  provincial  and  district  fisheries  services,  which  will 
facilitate the commercial application of research results by fish farmers, is expected to lead to 
additional improvements in aquaculture productivity at project sites. The training of fish farmers 
and demonstrations of various aquaculture systems will not only lead to the establishment of 
small-scale enterprises by fish farmers, but will also provide technically educated labor for 
medium-scale enterprises. The improvements in financial returns for aquaculture enterprises as 
a result of project activities should lead to more private sector participation. 
 
11.  The  Project  will  also  result  in:  (i)  environmental  benefits  arising  from  improved 
aquaculture resources management at the district and village levels; (ii) improved nutrition and 
health of rural populations from increases in food supply - especially in animal protein; (iii) 
enhanced inter-agency and public-private sector linkages through strengthened partnerships in 
aquaculture development; and (iv) empowerment of small fish farmers and rural communities 
with  knowledge  and  skills  in  community-based  aquaculture  and  culture-based  fisheries 
management. 
  
B.  Assessment of Financial Returns to Fish Farmers 
12.  Prior to being promoted in the project sites, the commercial viability of each type of 
activity will be assessed through site selection criteria. To determine their financial viability, a 
financial analysis for five representative activities at the farm level will be undertaken (grouper 
cage culture, mudcrab fattening, seaweed production, carp ponds culture, and tiger-shrimp 
cultivation).  All  of  the  representative  aquaculture  activities  exhibit  financial  returns  that 
significantly exceed the prevailing financial cost of capital of 22% (Table A12.1). Detailed fish-
farm budgets are presented in Supplementary Appendix D.

Appendix 12  49 
13.  Sensitivity  Analysis.  Sensitivity  analysis  is  undertaken  to  determine  the  effect  of 
identified risk factors that may have adverse impacts on the financial performance of these 
activities. For purposes of the analysis, three major risks are considered: (i) increase in variable 
costs  (feeds,  fish  seed,  fertilizers,  other  production  materials,  and  labor);  (ii)  decrease  in 
revenues resulting from production shortfalls or a decline in farmgate output prices (various 
factors could cause such a decline, such as an increase in marketing or transportation costs); 
and  (iii)  occurrence  of  disease  every  two  years  (which  would  decrease  output  10–50% 
depending on the cultivated fish species). The analysis indicates that it would take serious 
adverse impacts for the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) to decline to the prevailing 
weighted financial cost of capital of 22% (Table A12.1).

F.  Distribution of Project Benefits 
 
15.  Project benefits will accrue to three distinct groups: (i) producers, (ii) associate service 
providers, and (iii) consumers. The Project will have direct impacts on producers and indirect 
impacts on associated service providers of inputs such as seed, chemicals, and other supplies, 
as well as on the transport industry. In addition, the Project will contribute to national food 
security and provide a key source of protein to low income households. 
 
16.  The selection criteria for subproject sites and beneficiaries require beneficiaries to be 
poor (Appendix 5). According to the Central Bureau of Statistics, the average poverty and near

assessment of the feasibility of this investment and the cost-benefit analysis only consider direct 
project impacts, this assessment of benefits will focus only on the outcomes for direct project

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
      No  agreement?      No 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reducing poverty in Indonesia: 
Aquaculture has been playing an increasingly important role in ensuring food availability, providing household food 
security, and generating valuable foreign exchange and domestic revenues. Aside from contributing about one-fifth of 
the country’s estimated total fish production, the aquaculture subsector has been providing employment to some 
2.2 million  people,  representing  around  40%  of  the  total  number  of  people  employed  in  the  fisheries  sector. 
Aquaculture also absorbs much of the growing labor force that enters the job market each year, cushioning the 
economic hardships faced by people seeking gainful employment. 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  Targeted Intervention 
The country's aquaculture subsector suffers from low productivity as a result of technical, 
economic, and environmental factors. Small-scale fish farmers usually practice extensive 
culture, which gives low yields. These problems are compounded by the high prices of 
imported  production  inputs  and  a  lack  of  post-production  facilities  and  market 
infrastructure. In some areas, there have been outbreaks of fish and shrimp disease, 
usually triggered by poor environmental quality, inferior seed quality, and poor hatchery 
and culture management. Small-scale fish farmers also lack funds to shift to higher density 
farming or higher-value commodities, and cannot access credit from local banks and 
financial institutions. The combination of these factors has resulted in low incomes and 
poor quality of life for small-scale fish farmers. 
 
Based on results of the socioeconomic survey of selected households, the average poverty 
incidence among fish-farmer households in the five project districts is estimated at 34%. 
This figure is higher than the official Central Bureau of Statistics (BPS) estimate of overall 
poverty incidence in the five districts, which is 20.2%. This shows that the aquaculture 
sector in project districts is disproportionately poor compared with other economic sectors. 
Low incomes have led to a certain amount of deprivation within fish-farming households, as 
demonstrated by the following statistics: (i) 66% of households have poor access to and 
low utilization of quality health care and clinical services; (ii) 61% of families lack sustained 
access to a safe water; (iii) local kids get an average of only 5.5 years of schooling (the 
figure is lower for young girls); (iv) 32% of children under 5 years have substandard 
nutritional  status;  and  (v)  more  than  50%  of  women  primarily  work  at  unpaid  jobs, 
demonstrating a lack of income-generating opportunities in these communities.1 
 
To  address  the  poverty  issues  confronting  the  small-scale  fish  farmers  and  their 
households, the Project will introduce them to improved, sustainable, environment-friendly 
aquaculture practices and techniques. The Project will provide small-scale fish farmers with 
technical and financial assistance to launch and sustain small but income-generating 
aquaculture enterprises. Organizations of fish farmers—including women fish farmers—will 
be strengthened. And fish farmers will improve their skills and knowledge of aquaculture 
technologies with the help of extension workers and the support of the local fisheries office. 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
The Project followed a participatory approach in its formulation. The project framework and overall design were 
developed through a series of workshops, consultations, and discussions at the central, district, subdistrict, and village 
levels. Household surveys, supplemented by focus group discussions, were conducted in sample villages where poor 
aquaculture households made up the majority of respondents. The results of the workshops and consultations, as well 
as the local-level household surveys, were used as inputs in project design. Provisions were made to encourage 
participation in all the major project activities, especially in the refinement of the appropriate Project outputs for each 
district. Most project activities at the local level will be implemented by local governments and the Dinas Kelautan dan 
Perikanan (district fisheries services) in collaboration with community-based organizations (CBOs) and assisted by 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), thus enhancing local ownership of the Project. 
During the Project’s social preparation stage, an in-depth participatory rural appraisal will be conducted in each of the 
districts and subdistricts. The detailed work plan for each area will take into consideration the results of the rural 
appraisal. Village-level planning for project implementation will be spearheaded by the CBOs, and communities will be

Appendix 13  53 
represented in decision-making structures at the local level. CBOs and organized fish-farmer groups, as well as other 
community members, will be key players in the implementation of specific interventions in aquaculture production and 
microenterprise development.  The stakeholder analysis and participation plan are in Supplementary Appendix E. 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize positive impacts on women: 
The Project will support poor women in gaining access to resources, technical assistance, and capacity-building 
efforts for poverty reduction and food security. Women will be included in all project activities, including production-
inputs assistance and training programs. Likewise, women will be encouraged to participate in setting up, operating, 
and managing small-scale, culture-based fishery enterprises. The strengthening of women’s groups will ensure 
equitable opportunities for women to be represented and assume leadership positions in decision-making bodies, 
especially at the local level. To assure that gender concerns are addressed not only by the Project but also in the 
wider areas of education, nutrition, and child care, gender specialists will be hired to conduct gender training to 
sensitize local government officials and extension personnel of the Dinas Kelautan dan Perikanan to women’s needs 
and sociocultural issues.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  An initial environmental examination (IEE) of the proposed Sustainable Aquaculture 
Development for Food Security and Poverty Reduction Project was carried out to (i) ascertain its 
impacts on the environment and (ii) identify necessary measures to prevent or mitigate any 
adverse environmental impacts which could possibly arise from project implementation. Since 
the identification of specific aquaculture production activities and the final selection of sites for 
those activities will be made only during project implementation, a generic IEE was prepared. 
An  environmental  screening  of  the  project  components  and  proposed  interventions  was 
conducted to determine whether they would require an environmental impact assessment (EIA) 
or whether an IEE would suffice. The IEE was carried out in accordance with the Environmental 
Assessment Requirements of the Asian Development Bank (2003). The checklists used for 
determining  the  potential  environmental  impacts  of  prototype  interventions  are  provided  in 
ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agricultural and Natural Resources Development 
Projects (1991). 
 
B.  Description of the Project 
2.  The proposed Project will promote the adoption of sustainable, community-managed 
aquaculture in five districts. It will address existing problems within the Indonesian aquaculture 
industry and tap the vast potential of the country’s aquaculture resources, thereby reducing 
poverty and ensuring food security among fish-farming communities in rural inland and coastal 
areas. The Project will focus on the development and demonstration of small-scale, low-cost, 
low-input aquaculture production systems that are economically sound, environment friendly, 
and capable of being easily replicated by fish farmers organizations and small- to medium-scale 
private  entrepreneurs.  The  Project  will  promote  and  facilitate  partnerships  and  other 
arrangements between small fish farmers and commercial private sector operators in order to 
ensure ready markets for their produce and easy access to production inputs. It will likewise 
provide massive technical and extension support for fish farmer beneficiaries in order to ensure 
successful implementation, and include innovative mechanisms to assist organized fish farmer 
groups with their production inputs requirement. Through its institutional strengthening activities, 
the Project will assist DGA and the participating district governments in building their technical 
capacity  to  support  the  needs  of  the  beneficiaries,  their  communities,  and  the  Indonesian 
aquaculture industry as a whole. 
 
3.  The Project will be implemented in five districts in four provinces, namely: (i) Langkat in 
North  Sumatera  Province;  (ii)  Ogan  Komering  Ilir  (OKI)  in  South  Sumatera  Province;  (iii) 
Karawang  and  Sumedang  in  West  Java  Province;  and  (iv)  Buton  in  Southeast  Sulawesi 
Province. The Project will be implemented by DGA and the participating district governments 
over a six-year period (2007-2012) at a total cost of about $45 million equivalent. It will comprise 
three components, namely: (i) Aquaculture Production Enhancement, (ii) Aquaculture Support 
Services, and (iii) Institutional Strengthening and Project Management. The main interventions 
and principal parties involved in implementation of each of these components are summarized 
in Table A14.1.

D.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Plan 
 
6.  Institutional Arrangements. As the specific subprojects for implementation under the 
Project have yet to be identified and the subproject sites yet to be selected, a preliminary 
environmental management and monitoring plan (EMP) was prepared as part of the IEE. The 
EMP  includes  general  environmental  guidelines  and  criteria  for  subproject  selection,  and 
indicates the environmental management costs incorporated into the project budget. However, 
because environmental monitoring is an ongoing activity, and because the EMP needs to allow 
for future modifications based on real time requirements, it will be prepared by the project 
management office (PMO), with the assistance of an environment specialist, at the Project’s 
inception stage. The EMP will be implemented by technical personnel from the PIUs and district 
fisheries services, as well as NGOs and CBOs, under the supervision of the district environment 
service (Dinas Lingkungan Hidup) and with assistance from the environment specialist.

7.  Specific  subprojects  that  are  proposed  for  implementation  will  be  subjected  to 
environmental  screening,  and  an  IEE  (ANDAL)  will  be  conducted  for  those  subprojects 
classified under Category B in line with government environmental assessment requirements 
and procedures. Environmental screening and IEE preparation will be the responsibility of the 
PMO and PIUs, with assistance from the environment specialist. The ANDAL reports will be 
submitted for approval to the respective district environment services in the five project districts. 
 
8.  Water quality monitoring forms will be designed by the environment specialist, and an 
environmental monitoring subsystem will be incorporated as a subsystem of the aquaculture 
management information system (AMIS) to be designed and installed in DGA. The results of 
environmental monitoring done at the field level will be compiled at the PIUs and transmitted to 
DGA for storage and easy retrieval in the AMIS. As the PIUs will be linked to the central AMIS 
database through a wide area network (WAN), data accessibility should not be a problem. 
 
9.  Environmental  Monitoring.  The  monitoring  program  will  determine  the  extent  of 
variations in the levels of environmental indicators. Baseline conditions will be measured prior to 
the  establishment  of  project  facilities  in  an  area.  The  regular  monitoring  program  will  be 
formulated  thereafter  with  the  baseline  conditions  serving  as  minimum  parameters  to  be 
monitored to evaluate the effects of project activities. 
 
10.  Water quality monitoring will be conducted in (i) fishponds, supply and drainage canals, 
and  surrounding  areas;  (ii)  aquaculture  production  sites  in  freshwater,  brackishwater,  and 
marine areas; and (iii) areas where water from fishponds, fish processing, and other village 
activities is discharged. The following essential water quality parameters should be monitored, 
at least on a quarterly basis: (i) pH; (ii) dissolved oxygen; (iii) biochemical oxygen demand 
(BOD);  (iv)  nutrient  concentration  (nitrates,  nitrites,  ammonia,  phosphates);  (v)  suspended 
solids; and (vi) organochlorine residues. In open waters, water samples should be collected 
regularly from sampling sites within the project area and examined  in the laboratory. The 
sampling frequency will vary with the type of operation. Analysis of water samples will be done 
with water quality test kits provided by the Project to laboratories in the participating districts. 
Portable test kits will also be provided to local DKP technical personnel for routine monitoring of 
water quality in the private sector hatcheries and growout farms. Water quality monitoring 
results will be compared with both the official water quality standards established by the Menteri 
Negara Kepundudukan dan Lingkungan Hidup and the international water quality standards set 
by the World Health Organization. This is necessary to determine whether an indicator exceeds 
maximum allowable levels. 
 
E.  Public Consultation and Information Disclosure 
 
11.  In line with the participatory approach to project planning and preparation, numerous key 
interviews, local-level consultations, focus group discussions, and national and local workshops 
were organized and conducted at the five project sites between February and April 2004. These 
focus  group  discussions  and  workshops  were  designed  to  determine  the  most  pressing 
concerns of stakeholders and to obtain stakeholder input for consideration in project design.

60  Appendix 14 
Environmental issues and concerns figured prominently into the discussions and triggered the 
incorporation of environmental improvement measures in the project design. 
 
F.  Conclusions  
 
12.  The initial examination of likely environmental impacts of the proposed Project showed 
that  none  of  the  prototype  interventions  is  environmentally  critical  or  projected  to  create 
significant adverse or negative impacts on the environment. Only a few minor environmental 
impacts are likely as a result of factors related to site selection, construction, and operation, but 
these are small and avoidable or mitigable. Construction-related impacts are localized and 
temporary in nature and could be minimized through careful planning and the adoption of proper 
construction practices. Some potential impacts related to the operation of mariculture and land-
based aquaculture facilities have been identified, but environmental safeguards have been built 
into the project design to mitigate against these likely negative effects. 
 
13.  Overall,  the  Project  is  not  expected  to  result  in  significant  environmental  impacts. 
Instead,  the  Project  is  likely  to  bring  about  positive  benefits  in  the  form  of  (i)  increased 
production  of fish, shrimp, mollusks, and seaweeds through environment-friendly, sustainable 
aquaculture; (ii) enhancement of natural stocks of fish and other valuable species, whose 
populations have been overfished; (iii) improved quality of fish for human consumption; (iv) 
improved health, hygiene, and environmental sanitation among local community residents at the 
five project sites as a result of the provision of potable water and public toilets; and (v) greater 
public  awareness  of  the  need  for  sustainable  aquaculture  and  environmental  protection. 
Therefore, the preparation of an environmental impact assessment is not required, and this IEE 
could suffice for the purpose of this Project. 
 
14.  Nevertheless, environmental parameters should be included among the criteria used in 
the selection of project sites. Environmental conditions at project sites should also be monitored 
at least quarterly to determine changes in the levels of essential environmental parameters. 
Sharp changes could point to a need for remedial measures.
